newsitem.title: USA: U.S corp bond issuance at standstill ahead of data.
newsitem.headline: U.S corp bond issuance at standstill ahead of data.

text.p: The slow pace of corporate bond issuance is expected to carry on through the week as market players focus on Friday's highly anticipated U.S. jobs report, dealers said.
"It's been very quiet; we're still operating with lower staff levels," said one syndicate source. "Everyone is focusing on the employment numbers this week."
On Friday, the U.S. Labor Department will release its August figures on employment at 0830 EDT/1230 GMT.
In a Reuter poll, U.S. economists predicted an increase of 244,000 in nonfarm payrolls and expect the unemployment rate to dip slightly to 5.3 percent from 5.4 percent.

Thinner post-holiday staffing combined with upcoming key economic data have kept the new issue calendar up in the air, dealers said. A few deals are said to be in the pipeline although no official dates have been set, they added.
Capital One Bank COF.N is expected to price $200 million in 10-year debt via JP Morgan. The issue is puttable in the third year, syndicate sources said.
Commonwealth Aluminum Corp is expected to price $100 million in senior subordinated 144A notes via Morgan Stanley, sources said.
Also, Euromax International is expected to isssue $125 million in 144A notes, they added.
In the government market, the benchmark U.S. 30-year bond is trading off 12/32 at 95-25/32 to yield 7.09 percent.
